unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities: Solar Rooftop Subsidies See Increased Uptake in Maharashtra**
normalised: energy and utilities: solar rooftop subsidies see increased uptake in maharashtra

unnormalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra - The Maharashtra Energy Development Agency (MEDA) reports a significant increase in the adoption of solar rooftop systems, spurred by attractive government subsidies. The "Surya Maharashtra Yojana" offers subsidies up to 40% for residential installations covering up to 3 kW capacity, and 20% for systems between 3 kW and 10 kW.
normalised: mumbai, maharashtra - the maharashtra energy development agency (M E D A) reports a significant increase in the adoption of solar rooftop systems, spurred by attractive government subsidies. the "surya maharashtra yojana" offers subsidies up to forty percent for residential installations covering up to three kilowatt capacity, and twenty percent for systems between three kilowatt and ten kilowatt.

unnormalised: Dr. Anil Desai, Director of MEDA, stated that the initiative aims to power 5 lakh homes with clean energy by 2026. Applications for subsidies are now streamlined through a dedicated online portal.
normalised: doctor anil desai, director of M E D A, stated that the initiative aims to power five lakh homes with clean energy by two thousand and twenty six. applications for subsidies are now streamlined through a dedicated online portal.

unnormalised: This has led to a noticeable rise in installations, especially in urban areas like Pune and Nagpur. A typical 3 kW system, covering approximately 300 sq ft, can significantly reduce electricity bills for a family. The subsidy scheme has made solar power accessible to a wider section of the population, with many middle-class families opting for rooftop solutions.

unnormalised: Rs. 1,500 crore has been allocated for the scheme over the next three years. Officials predict that this will not only boost renewable energy adoption but also generate employment opportunities in the installation and maintenance sectors. Concerns remain regarding the grid's capacity to handle the influx of solar power.
